growing.sun: Full sun for best yields, tolerates partial shade
growing.water: Moderate to high; consistent moisture is important, especially during fruit development
growing.soil: Rich, well-draining, slightly acidic (pH 5.5-6.5); enriched with compost or organic matter

planting.spacing: 2-3 feet between plants; 6-8 feet between rows
planting.whenToPlant: Early spring while dormant; in mild climates, late fall is also possible
planting.propagation: Suckers or root cuttings; raspberries naturally spread by producing new canes from roots
planting.depth: Shallow planting; set crown just at or slightly above soil level
avoidPlantingNear: Nightshades (tomatoes, potatoes, peppers — these can spread verticillium wilt)

pruning: For summer-fruiting types: prune fruited canes to ground level after harvest; leave strong new canes for next year
For ever-bearing types: can prune all canes to ground in late winter for single large fall crop, or selectively prune for two harvests
careAndMaintenance.stakingSupport: Trellis or support recommended to keep canes upright, improve air flow, and ease harvesting

harvestingAndUsage.whenToHarvest: When berries are fully colored, plump, and easily detach from the core (receptacle)
harvestingAndUsage.howToHarvest: Pick gently by hand to avoid bruising; harvest every 2-3 days during peak season
harvestingAndUsage.preservation: Excellent for fresh eating, freezing, drying, jams, jellies, syrups, baking

pollinators: Self-fertile but benefit from bees and other pollinators for improved fruit size and yield
wildlifeResistance: Birds are fond of raspberries; netting may be necessary to protect the crop

Summer-fruiting.description: Produces berries on second-year canes (floricanes); one large crop in early to mid-summer

Ever-bearing.description: Also called fall-bearing or primocane-fruiting; produces two crops — a smaller one in early summer on second-year canes, and a larger one in fall on first-year canes
